author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Pompeo lashes out at reporter over Ukraine questions.
description: A reporter for NPR recounted that the secretary of state shouted at her, using an expletive and demanding, “Do you think Americans care about Ukraine?”
content: As the hearing was underway, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo got into it with a reporter for NPR, Mary Louise Kelly, after she asked about his failure to stand up for the former ambassador to Ukraine, Marie L. Yovanovitch. Ms. Kelly reported that Mr. Pompeo shouted at her, using an expletive and demanding, “Do you think Americans care about Ukraine?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Republican senators are visibly upset by Schiff’s reference to CBS report.
description: A CBS report said Republican senators had been warned to “vote against the president and your head will be on a pike.”
content: Republican senators had mostly been listening stone-faced to Representative Adam B. Schiff, Democrat of California and the lead House manager, make his closing arguments. But when Mr. Schiff referred to a CBS report that said Republican senators had been warned to “vote against the president and your head will be on a pike,” a number of senators muttered “not true.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: New York’s Subway Boss Quit: Will Your Commute Get Worse?
description: Andy Byford has been praised for reversing the decline of the system. Now transit leaders “don’t want to lose the momentum.”
content: When Andy Byford was recruited to run the New York City subway, the system was in crisis. Trains broke down routinely. A series of accidents raised safety concerns. Constant delays made riders late for work, meetings and medical appointments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Working-Class Families in Despair
description: Readers discuss an article about the high death rate from drug and alcohol abuse and suicide in the hometown of the columnist Nicholas Kristof.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Pompeo accuses a reporter of lying.
description: Mr. Pompeo issued a statement to denounce a reporter who said on the air this week that he had privately lashed out at her with profanities
content: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who has tried to distance himself from what he calls “the noise” of the impeachment proceedings, issued an extraordinary official statement Saturday accusing a veteran NPR reporter who pressed him about his role in the Ukraine affair had “lied” to him and was a “shameful” example of the “unhinged” anti-Trump news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: The White House legal team will begin presenting its case.
description: The president’s lawyers will offer a radically different view of the facts and the Constitution, while seeking to undercut the whole process by painting it as illegitimate and unfounded.
content: President Trump’s legal team plans to mount an aggressive defense that looks more like offense on Saturday as it opens its side in the Senate impeachment trial by attacking his accusers as partisan witch-hunters trying to remove him because they cannot beat him at the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Jeffrey E. Singer
title: As Coronavirus and Fear Spread to the U.S., Chinese-Americans Rush to Help
description: Facing the brunt of scrutiny in the United States, Chinese-Americans have also scrambled to help friends and family in China.
content: Amy Lee-Ludovicy’s children and their classmates were supposed to be on a chartered bus into New York City on Friday morning, destined for a visit to Chinatown ahead of the Lunar New Year celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 25, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 25, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about an invitation extended to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to visit the White House misstated President Trump’s itinerary when he spoke to reporters aboard Air Force One. He was en route from Joint Base Andrews to Doral, Fla., to speak at the Republican National Committee’s winter meeting, not on his way back from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Dangerous Virus Mutes China’s ‘Happiest Day’
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 25, 2020.
content: “The doctors were crying that they were helpless to do anything.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rion Amilcar Scott
title: The Stories in This Chicago Housing Project Could Fill a Book
description: And in Jasmon Drain’s debut collection, “Stateway’s Garden,” they do.
content: A story late in the Chicago author Jasmon Drain’s debut, “Stateway’s Garden,” begins: “Our mothers take credit, but in Stateway we raised ourselves.” It’s a telling sentence, a kind of key to the whole enterprise. We are introduced from the first page to a cast of tenants living in the low-income housing project in the mid-1980s, individuals who recur across the collection, finding different ways to connect, disconnect and let one another down. But, much like the tenement in Gloria Naylor’s “The Women of Brewster Place,” it’s these characters’ living space that is the book’s real protagonist. That is, the high-rises themselves take on traits and modes of agency that shift and evolve from story to story — each time a familiar name is brought back to the stage, he or she feels recontextualized, born anew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: White House team plans to refer repeatedly to Hunter Biden.
description: President Trump’s lawyers appear fairly confident that the Democrats will not have enough votes to call witnesses at trial.
content: When President Trump’s defense lawyers begin to outline their case on Saturday, they will consider everything that Democrats have raised in their own presentation to have opened the door for discussion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: House testimony undermines argument that Trump engaged in quid pro quo, defense says.
description: “There can’t be a threat without the person knowing he’s being threatened,” said the lawyer Michael Purpura.
content: Another of President Trump’s lawyers, Michael Purpura, the deputy White House counsel, repeatedly pointed to aspects of the testimony during the House inquiry that he said undermined the argument that Mr. Trump was engaging in a quid pro quo.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 77 Vegetarian Comfort Food Recipes
description: Shakshuka, Indian-ish nachos, and more recipes.
content: This weekend, make French onion macaroni and cheese, Priya and Ritu Krishna’s Indian-ish nachos (above), a cheesy, spicy black bean bake, or any of the recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Cipollone leads off for White House legal team.
description: The defense lawyers planned to focus on aspects of the Ukraine affair that he accused Democrats of trying to hide.
content: Pat Cipollone, the White House counsel, led off for President Trump’s team by saying they would focus on aspects of the Ukraine controversy that he accused Democrats of trying to hide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Who decides whether any executive privilege claim is valid?
description: Representative Adam B. Schiff, who is leading the House impeachment managers, has proposed that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. could rule on the validity of any such claim.
content: Senate allies of President Trump, hoping to keep Republicans from breaking ranks and joining Democrats in voting to subpoena witnesses and documents, have argued that the president would invoke executive privilege — raising the question of how such a clash would be resolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Managers wrap up their opening arguments.
description: Representative Adam B. Schiff, whose stirring speech on Thursday night gained grudging plaudits from some Republicans, appeared to lose ground on Friday.
content: House Democrats finished their opening arguments on Friday in the impeachment trial of President Trump, after spending nearly 24 hours over three days laying out their case that the president abused his oath of office and obstructed Congress by pressuring the leader of Ukraine to investigate his political rivals and concealing his misdeeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aidan Gardiner
title: ‘There Are Too Many Minefields’: Readers on Swiping and Dating in the Trump Era
description: More than 200 people told us about their political deal breakers, the subtle profile clues they look for and their connections across the aisle.
content: At a time when politics have become so intensely personal and divisive, how are people navigating the topic in the already fraught world of online dating?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean François Fogel
title: Ending Systemic Racism Is the Revolution Cuba Needs
description: Afro-Cubans have long been pushed to the margins. The leaders of the post-Castro era must work to change the course of history.
content: PARIS — Cuba under Fidel and Raúl Castro saw its share of No. 3 men. Occupying the country’s most visible position of power after the Castros meant that getting the boot was always a possibility, and perhaps even an inevitability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Aubry Kaplan
title: My Piece of the American Id
description: Does equality in the age of Trump mean I can be irrationally angry, too?
content: The president’s freewheeling racism, emanating year after year from the top of the American political order, has made me more hostile toward white folks and whiteness than I’ve ever been in my life. Despite the fact that I’ve written provocatively (so I’m told) about racial matters for years, this hostility is new — and I’m increasingly unafraid to express it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Bowen Yang of ‘S.N.L.’ Is a Smash. And a Mensch.
description: The show’s first Chinese-American cast member talks resisting conversion therapy, playing politicians and quitting Twitter.
content: Bowen Yang went wild and crazy when he was christened as the newest cast member on “Saturday Night Live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Bowen Yang of ‘S.N.L.’ Is a Smash. And a Mensch.
description: The show’s first Chinese-American cast member talks resisting conversion therapy, playing politicians and quitting Twitter.
content: Bowen Yang went wild and crazy when he was christened as the newest cast member on “Saturday Night Live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Trump Impeachment: Highlights of Saturday’s Trial
description: After a three-day presentation from House Democrats, President Trump’s lawyers took the stage in a short Saturday session to begin arguing against his removal. Here were the highlights.
content: After three days of arguments by the House managers prosecuting President Trump for high crimes and misdemeanors, the president’s lawyers presented the senators a radically different view of the facts and the Constitution, seeking to turn the Democrats’ charges back on them while denouncing the whole process as illegitimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Maggie Astor
title: Sanders, Biden, Clinton? This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Paying attention to the impeachment trial this week? Us too. But here are 7 things that happened on the campaign trail you may have missed.
content: The Iowa caucuses are just around the corner — but with the impeachment trial underway in Washington, the presidential campaign is in a strange sort of suspended animation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Pompeo Lashes Out at Reporter and Challenges Her to Find Ukraine on a Map
description: “He shouted at me for about the same amount of time as the interview itself had lasted,” said Mary Louise Kelly of NPR.
content: Update: On Saturday, Mike Pompeo, the top American diplomat, lashed out at a reporter from NPR and what he called the “unhinged” news media in an extraordinary statement, apparently angered by her description of an interview she conducted with him on Iran and Ukraine. Read more about how it ignited outrage among foreign policy experts, scholars of diplomacy and press freedom advocates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Can the Grammys Be Trusted?
description: Younger artists have been suspicious of the music industry’s “biggest night” for years. New allegations of misconduct at the Recording Academy seem to confirm the worst.
content: When Deborah Dugan took her post as the chief executive of the Recording Academy, which oversees the Grammy Awards, in August, she inherited an organization in meltdown and was tasked with getting it back on track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Coronavirus Exposes Core Flaws, and Few Strengths, in China’s Governance
description: While China can mobilize a huge national response to the outbreak, its response to the crisis is also a lesson in how the country’s political weak points can carry grave consequences for world health.
content: It was the initial news reports that first suggested China’s political system might be getting in the way of its ability to confront the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Could Trump Muzzle John Bolton? The Limits of Executive Privilege, Explained
description: If senators vote to subpoena testimony for the impeachment trial, the president may not be able to block or delay a willing witness.
content: WASHINGTON — Republican senators allied with President Trump are increasingly arguing that the Senate should not call witnesses or subpoena documents for his impeachment trial because Mr. Trump has threatened to invoke executive privilege, and a legal fight would take too long to resolve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Flanagan
title: How Does a Nation Adapt to Its Own Murder?
description: Australia is going up in flames, and its government calls for resilience while planning for more coal mines.
content: BRUNY ISLAND, Australia — The name of the future is Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Notorious D.J.T. on Trial
description: Fidget spinners and spinning Republicans make the best of a bad case for Donald John Trump.
content: Republicans know very well who they are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What if It Were Obama on Trial?
description: Consider Trump’s impeachment from some other angles.
content: What if it were President Barack Obama who was the subject of the Senate impeachment trial? How would we feel then?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Could Trump Muzzle John Bolton? The Limits of Executive Privilege, Explained
description: If senators vote to subpoena testimony for the impeachment trial, the president may not be able to block or delay a willing witness.
content: WASHINGTON — Republican senators allied with President Trump are increasingly arguing that the Senate should not call witnesses or subpoena documents for his impeachment trial because Mr. Trump has threatened to invoke executive privilege, and a legal fight would take too long to resolve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Spurs China to Suspend Tours Abroad and Xi to Warn of a ‘Grave Situation’
description: Concern over the outbreak has crept closer to central government offices and the ruling Communist Party’s seat of power.
content: This briefing has ended. Read about developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China’s Omnivorous Markets Are in the Eye of a Lethal Outbreak Once Again
description: The coronavirus that has spread from Wuhan has been linked to the sale of live wildlife at a market that experts describe as a perfect incubator for novel pathogens.
content: LANGFANG, China — The typical market in China has fruits and vegetables, butchered beef, pork and lamb, whole plucked chickens — with heads and beaks attached — and live crabs and fish, spewing water out of churning tanks. Some sell more unusual fare, including live snakes, turtles and cicadas, guinea pigs, bamboo rats, badgers, hedgehogs, otters, palm civets, even wolf cubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Commemorating the Victims of Canada’s ‘Gay Purge’
description: A national memorial will soon rise to the thousands of people whose careers were ruined because of their sexual orientation.
content: One of the most extraordinary things about the “gay purge” of Canada’s public servants, members of the military and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police is that it continued until 1992. That was a quarter-century after Pierre Elliott Trudeau, then the justice minister, declared that “there’s no place for the state in the bedrooms of the nation” as he introduced the legislation that repealed the nation’s laws banning homosexuality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Trump Impeachment: Making a Case Against a President, and Against Tuning Out
description: The Democratic impeachment case used passion and video clips to substitute for witnesses and fight apathy.
content: They played video. They brought graphics. They cited Alexander Hamilton so many times, they may owe royalties to Lin-Manuel Miranda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Cave’ and a New ‘Sabrina’ Season
description: A Syrian documentary is on National Geographic. And “Chilling Adventures of Sabrina” returns to Netflix.
content: THE CAVE (2019) 9 p.m. on National Geographic. “There is no endgame here,” Ben Kenigsberg said of this documentary in The New York Times. Feras Fayaad, who was born in Syria, directed most of the film remotely, relying on cinematographers to record the lives of Dr. Amani Ballour and her patients in a secret, underground hospital outside Damascus. A hero in the film and in her community, Ballour is one of the rare women doctors in the country, and she is constantly challenged for it. This is the least of her worries in the hospital, known as the cave. Above ground — where war planes are zooming overhead — the demolition caused by bombings, malnutrition and chemical attacks brings Syrians of all ages to her care, where all she can do is her best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: White House team will go after Trump’s accusers in unrelenting terms.
description: In keeping with their combative client’s own style, President Trump’s lawyers plan to insist he did nothing wrong,
content: In keeping with their combative client’s own style, President Trump’s lawyers plan not only to insist he did nothing wrong, but also to go after his accusers in unrelenting terms, painting them as partisans not prosecutors. The lawyers hope to turn the tables on the Democrats by hurling back at them some of the same allegations they have made against their client. By their account, the Democrats are the ones who are corrupt liars who sought foreign help and are now abusing their power to steal an election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: Luis Rojas and the Mets Embrace Their Second Chance
description: Passed over last fall in the Mets’ search for a manager, Rojas will take over the team now that Carlos Beltran is gone.
content: When Mets General Manager Brodie Van Wagenen introduced Luis Rojas as the team’s new manager at Citi Field on Friday afternoon, Van Wagenen declared the occasion a proud day. He welcomed Rojas, who has been with the organization for 15 seasons, as “one of our own,” and cited Rojas’s consistency as a key factor in the decision to promote him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: It’s Time to Ask What Africa Needs
description: Yes, Europe’s interests are important. But they shouldn’t be allowed to drive every decision in soccer.
content: Enjoying this newsletter every week? Forward it to a friend and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Defense case may focus on the actions of the other side.
description: White House lawyers plan to discuss in detail the Bidens, as well as to assail the F.B.I. for its surveillance of a onetime Trump campaign aide.
content: President Trump faces two articles of impeachment, for abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, stemming from his effort to pressure Ukraine to announce investigations into his Democratic rivals while withholding nearly $400 million in congressionally approved security aid in what a government agency called a violation of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: White House team will go after Trump’s accusers in unrelenting terms.
description: In keeping with their combative client’s own style, President Trump’s lawyers plan to insist he did nothing wrong,
content: In keeping with their combative client’s own style, President Trump’s lawyers plan not only to insist he did nothing wrong, but also to go after his accusers in unrelenting terms, painting them as partisans not prosecutors. The lawyers hope to turn the tables on the Democrats by hurling back at them some of the same allegations they have made against their client. By their account, the Democrats are the ones who are corrupt liars who sought foreign help and are now abusing their power to steal an election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: What to Watch For in Trump’s Impeachment Trial on Saturday
description: House impeachment managers will step back as the president’s legal team fires its first salvo.
content: President Trump’s lawyers will begin presenting their defense on Saturday, hoping to deliver a sharp counterargument to three days of presentations that House impeachment managers wrapped up Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Catie Edmondson
title: Managers’ show of evidence could undercut their call for new documents and witnesses.
description: They took boxes filled with 28,578 pages of transcripts and other evidence collected during the inquiry.
content: Their argument finished, the House managers made one last stab on Saturday morning to underscore the power of their impeachment case against President Trump by marching from the House to the Senate with boxes filled with 28,578 pages of transcripts and other evidence collected during their inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Your Credit Score May Soon Change. Here’s Why.
description: FICO is tweaking its all-important formula. Scores will rise for about 40 million people and drop for another 40 million.
content: Your credit score — that all-important passport within the financial world — may be about to change. And it won’t necessarily be because of anything you did or didn’t do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump’s team mounts its defense as it turns Democrats’ charges back on them.
description: “They’re asking you to tear up all of the ballots all across the country on your own initiative, take that decision away from the American people,” the White House counsel said of the House managers.
content: As the trial moved into a new phase after three days of arguments by the House managers prosecuting President Trump for high crimes and misdemeanors, the president’s lawyers presented the senators a radically different view of the facts and the Constitution, seeking to turn the Democrats’ charges back on them while denouncing the whole process as illegitimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Invested in Each Other, and the Acela
description: For two years, either Kara Diamond or Andrew Stahl spent many a weekend traveling between Philadelphia and New York.
content: Kara Michelle Diamond and Andrew Nicholas Stahl were married Jan. 25 at the Brown Hotel in Louisville, Ky. Jeremy Crouthamel, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: P.S.: Fans Still Love ‘To All the Boys’
description: Noah Centineo, Lana Condor and hundreds who loved the Netflix rom-com hit walk into a movie theater for the sequel. Cue collective squealing.
content: Nothing truly bonds hundreds of young women like collectively watching Peter Kavinsky, the swoon-inducing love interest of Netflix’s “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before” films, do something dashing onscreen — and releasing a wave of ear-shattering screams in unison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Clayton Christensen, Guru of ‘Disruptive Innovation,’ Dies at 67
description: He broke ground with his assertion that the factors that helped the best companies succeed were also the reasons some of those same companies failed.
content: Clayton M. Christensen, a professor at Harvard Business School whose groundbreaking 1997 book, “The Innovator’s Dilemma,” outlined his theories about the impact of what he called “disruptive innovation” on leading companies and catapulted him to superstar status as a management guru, died on Thursday at a hospital in Boston. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Gracie Gold Skates to 12th Place and a Standing Ovation at U.S. Championships
description: Gold, the Olympian whose career was sidetracked by mental illness, was moved to tears as the audience saluted her in a significant comeback performance.
content: Gracie Gold, the Olympic figure skater whose career was halted by a battle with mental illness, received a standing ovation on Friday night at the United States national championships after completing a stirring free skate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: One Trump lawyer once worked for Comey.
description: Patrick Philbin was a senior official in the Justice Department under President George W. Bush.
content: Patrick Philbin, the White House lawyer arguing on behalf of President Trump on the Senate floor on Saturday, once worked for James B. Comey, not exactly a favorite of his current boss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Argument Erupts in Guantánamo Court Over Use of the Term ‘Torture’
description: A military judge said he would decide before the trial of five men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks whether their treatment in C.I.A. prisons amounted to torture.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: ‘Doorbell Ditch’ Prank Led to Crash That Killed 3 Teens, Officials Say
description: Prosecutors said that a Southern California man intentionally rammed into a car full of teenagers after they tricked him.
content: A man who the authorities contend deliberately crashed his car into another one on a Southern California road last Sunday, killing three of the six teenagers inside, did so because the group had played a so-called doorbell ditch prank on him, prosecutors said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Round of Upsets at Australian Open as 6 of Top 10 Women’s Seeds Lose
description: Pliskova, Svitolina and Bencic joined Osaka, Serena Williams and Wozniacki among the high-profile casualties in a previously placid tournament.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — After a fraught lead-up to the Australian Open, with concerns about the tournament’s ability to handle Melbourne’s worsened air quality because of nearby bushfires, the first four days of play offered clear air and straightforward matches that let the top women breathe easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Fancy Name for a Prison Sentence
description: Steal yourself some time to crack this Stella Zawistowski puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I have been waiting for a Stella Zawistowski puzzle, and we’re lucky to get it on a weekend. Ms. Zawistowski is a supersonic force of nature in the crossword solving world as well as a powerlifter, a scientifically improbable combination of speed and strength.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Emily Cochrane
title: Republicans criticize Schiff over ‘head on a pike’ comments.
description: “I’m not intimidated,” said Senator Richard Shelby, Republican of Alabama. “That was probably a little bit overboard.”
content: Republicans continued to complain Saturday about Representative Adam B. Schiff’s “head on a pike” comment from the night before, with one saying it was so offensive because of its implication that senators were running scared and were intimidated by President Trump. That suggest did not go down well on the Senate floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Margo Lion, Producer of ‘Hairspray’ and More, Dies at 75
description: In an era when big-budget theater was an increasingly corporate affair, Ms. Lion was a proudly independent producer.
content: Margo Lion, a theater producer who was largely responsible for bringing “Jelly’s Last Jam” and “Hairspray” to Broadway and played a major role in other important shows, including “Angels in America,” died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: 75 Years After Auschwitz Liberation, Worry That ‘Never Again’ Is Not Assured
description: Amid a surge of anti-Semitism and a rise in dehumanizing political rhetoric, there is fear that the horrific lessons of the death camp are being lost.
content: AUSCHWITZ-BIRKENAU, Poland — Even before the gas chambers were destroyed and the savage toll of years of industrialized mass murder revealed to the world, prisoners at the largest Nazi concentration camp were already repeating two words: Never again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
title: Tom Steyer Spends Millions in South Carolina. Black Voters Reap the Benefit.
description: Seeking inroads in the state, Mr. Steyer, a hedge-fund billionaire, is paying black vendors, hiring black staff members and appearing in rural outposts, lavishing money and attention. It’s paying dividends.
content: HARTSVILLE, S.C. — While leading Democratic presidential candidates make a last-minute push in Iowa and Michael R. Bloomberg looks ahead to Super Tuesday, Tom Steyer has his eye on a different prize: South Carolina. And he’s spending millions of dollars to court the black voters who are crucial to success in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Lamar Alexander, Set to Leave Office, Is G.O.P. Wild Card on Witnesses
description: The Tennessee Republican was a protege of Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., another Republican from Tennessee, who turned against Richard Nixon. Now Mr. Alexander may hold the fate of President Trump in his hands.
content: WASHINGTON — The ghost of Howard H. Baker Jr., the Republican senator from Tennessee who turned against Richard M. Nixon during Watergate, is hovering over Senator Lamar Alexander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Trump’s Best Defense
description: It’s that he wants to be L.B.J., not Mussolini. (But that’s still a problem.)
content: In the debate over whether Donald Trump deserves impeachment, a curious partisan reversal has taken place. Trump’s opponents are suddenly constitutional originalists, seeking to ground their case for impeachment in 18th-century history and founding-era rhetoric. Meanwhile, his most persuasive defenders are more likely to invoke a kind of living constitutionalism, in which the limited, sporadic way that impeachment has been actually used over the centuries matters more than what the founders contemplated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Why Do We Have an Electoral College Again?
description: A pair of new Supreme Court cases reveal a foundational flaw in how we pick the president.
content: Who elects the president of the United States?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Of All Trump’s Defenses, This Is the Lamest
description: Only the voters can send the president packing? That’s a joke.
content: Once the Senate concludes its trial of President Trump, it should go into recess. Until next January. The House, too. Lawmakers shouldn’t pass legislation, consider nominations or make any important decisions whatsoever: This is an election year, and the voters will soon weigh in on the direction of America. The nation’s business should await that judgment, lest members of Congress contradict it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Schiff warns that not removing Trump would be ‘an unending injury’ to U.S.
description: The lawmaker implored senators not to set a precedent that would cede Congress’s investigative authority to the executive branch for generations to come.
content: In his closing remarks, Representative Adam Schiff of California, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, outlined a dire warning: that a failure to reprove President Trump for obstructing Congress would inflict “an unending injury to this country” because “the balance of power that our founders set out will never be the same.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Impeachment Briefing: ‘Take Her Out’
description: After a tape of President Trump talking about the ambassador to Ukraine emerged, the secretary of state lashed out at a reporter’s question.
content: The trial resumes at 10 a.m., and it’s the White House’s turn to make opening arguments. Mr. Trump’s legal team said that they only planned to use a few hours of their allotted time to give a brief overview of its case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘He Is a Dictator’: Democrats Finish Opening Arguments
description: The House impeachment managers completed their opening arguments in the Senate trial of President Trump.
content: The House impeachment managers completed their opening arguments in the Senate trial of President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump will face a more receptive audience in the Republican-controlled Senate.
description: The main priority for the president’s legal team is not to undermine their own advantage or give wavering moderate Republican senators reasons to support Democratic requests for witnesses and documentary evidence.
content: With the odds stacked against him in the Democratic-run House, President Trump refused to send lawyers to participate in Judiciary Committee hearings last month, complaining that he was not given sufficient due process. But he faces a more receptive audience in the Republican-controlled Senate, where the White House has been working in tandem with Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Ryan
title: 6 Items to Stuff in Your Ski Jacket Pockets
description: Sure, you’ll remember gloves and a helmet. But there’s other important gear to bring along for a successful day on the slopes.
content: A day spent skiing or snowboarding consists of fast-moving hits of glorious exhilaration interspersed with glacial stretches spent waiting in line and riding lifts. Often the key to maximizing the fun and minimizing the cold and boredom is how well you prepare. Along with a neck gaiter, waterproof gloves and, of course, snacks — one Wirecutter staffer stashes mini Snickers bars in all his pockets — consider bringing along the following items to ensure your day is memorable in all the right ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump lashes out at his Democratic rivals.
description: The tweet underscores what his lawyers already know: that as they begin defending him, Mr. Trump will be watching.
content: President Trump was up early Saturday, lashing out at “lyin’ cheatin’ liddle’ Adam ‘Shifty Schiff” and other Democrats, starting what could be his Twitter play-by-play of his lawyers finally mounting a defense in his impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: A Tribute to Eli Manning: ‘No Giant Will Ever Wear No. 10 Again’
description: Former Giants players and coaches gathered as Manning, 39, formally announced his retirement from the N.F.L.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — John Mara, the co-owner of the Giants, choked back tears and his voice cracked as he recalled the last game attended by Wellington Mara, his father and the longtime patriarch of the Giants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: 85,000 Pieces From Beloved Chinatown Museum Likely Destroyed in Fire
description: The president of the Museum of Chinese in America said that she was “just distraught” and that the collection was one of a kind.
content: The 85,000 items, some dating to the 19th century, told the rich story of the Chinese migration to the United States: textiles, restaurant menus, handwritten letters, tickets for ship’s passage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Staatsballett Berlin Leaders to Leave Prematurely
description: After only a year together on the job, Johannes Ohman and Sasha Waltz are stepping down. He will lead another house, and she will to return to choreography.
content: BERLIN — Sasha Waltz and Johannes Ohman, the joint artistic directors of the Staatsballet Berlin, announced this week they would step down at the end of 2020, though they’ve run the company together since only last year and signed on with five-year contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Gordon Sondland got it wrong, the president’s lawyers said.
description: The president’s lawyers insist that the ambassador to the European Union may have assumed there was a connection between security aid and the investigations but that he was wrong.
content: “Not a single witness testified that the president himself said that there was any connection between any investigations and security assistance and a presidential meeting or anything else,” said Michael Purpura, one of the president’s lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump impeachment lawyer once worked for his nemesis, Comey.
description: Patrick Philbin, who argued on the president’s behalf on Saturday, was a close ally of James B. Comey.
content: Patrick Philbin, one of the White House lawyers who argued on behalf of President Trump on the Senate floor on Saturday, once worked for James B. Comey, not exactly a favorite of his current boss.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: Fred Piscop takes us out to the ranch — the bird ranch.
content: SPLIT DECISIONS — I am trying to evangelize for all of the Variety puzzles this year, which is easy and natural for almost every challenge but this one, Split Decisions. I have nothing against Fred Piscop and his intricate, wonderful creations: I just find them hard to solve, and harder to explain how to solve. Turns out, that’s the real issue. Split Decisions puzzles are visually self-explanatory, and I don’t approach them with any special finesse or skill that I can impart to you, readers, so I’m really just the host here. Acknowledging that not only takes the pressure off, it made this solve, which has some really evocative words, much more fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
title: Glenn Greenwald in Bolsonaro’s Brazil: ‘I Trigger a Lot of Their Primal Rage’
description: The American journalist has found himself at the center of another political firestorm, this time over press freedom in Brazil.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Reading through the hacked cellphone messages of Brazilian prosecutors and judges, Glenn Greenwald knew he had a blockbuster story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Few G.O.P. Senators Display Any Hint of Being Swayed by Democrats’ Arguments
description: While the Senate verdict on impeachment could come soon, the public judgment will not be rendered until November.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats were prepared and passionate as they laid out over three draining days in the Senate a detailed argument for impeaching and removing President Trump. What they do not appear to have been is persuasive to the critical handful of Republicans who hold the key to their immediate objective: gaining access to witnesses and documents that could cement their case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Emotional Schiff Speech Goes Viral, Delighting the Left and Enraging the Right
description: Representative Adam B. Schiff took a risk in telling senators they must convict and remove President Trump because “you know you can't trust this president to do what's right for this country.”
content: WASHINGTON — Senator James M. Inhofe, a conservative Republican from Oklahoma, has made clear that he intends to vote to acquit President Trump. But after Representative Adam B. Schiff’s fiery speech Thursday night calling for the president’s removal, Mr. Inhofe felt compelled to give his fellow lawmaker some grudging respect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Who Are Trump’s Impeachment Defense Lawyers?
description: The president’s legal team must maintain his support in the Senate while arguing his case to a broader jury: voters watching at home.
content: President Trump has expanded his legal team in hopes of securing a quick acquittal in his Senate impeachment trial. The lawyers he has enlisted include frequent guests on Fox News and former independent counsels who investigated President Bill Clinton. Together, they must maintain Mr. Trump’s support in the Senate while arguing his case to a broader jury: voters watching at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Lawyers zero in on the Mueller inquiry.
description: Jay Sekulow accused the House Democratic managers of having “tried once again to re-litigate the Mueller case.”
content: President Trump’s defense lawyers echoed one of their client’s frequent lines of attack as they began their arguments on Saturday: that Democrats have been out to get him since long before Ukraine was a household word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Trump Calls for Ambassador’s Firing in Recording
description: President Trump called for the removal of Marie L. Yovanovitch as the United States ambassador to Ukraine, a 2018 recording of a conversation between the president, Lev Parnas and others shows.
content: President Trump called for the removal of Marie L. Yovanovitch as the United States ambassador to Ukraine, a 2018 recording of a conversation between the president, Lev Parnas and others shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Sydney Ember
title: Sanders Seizes Lead in Volatile Iowa Race, Times Poll Finds
description: With solid support from liberals, Mr. Sanders appears to be peaking just as the caucuses approach. But many Iowa voters said they could still change their mind.
content: DES MOINES — Senator Bernie Sanders has opened up a lead in Iowa just over a week before the Democratic caucuses, consolidating support from liberals and benefiting from divisions among more moderate presidential candidates who are clustered behind him, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll of likely caucusgoers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Gantz to Meet Trump on Peace Plan, but Alone, Not With Netanyahu
description: Seemingly cornered into an awkward meeting with his political rival and the U.S. president, Benny Gantz finds a way to avoid aiding Benjamin Netanyahu — without offending the White House.
content: RAMAT GAN, Israel — Benny Gantz, the former Israeli military chief making a third attempt to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, said Saturday that he would visit President Trump on his own in Washington on Monday to discuss a White House proposal for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Indonesia Releases U.S. Journalist Detained Over Visa Issue
description: The authorities had threatened a yearslong prison sentence for Philip Jacobson, who was jailed for three days. He is likely to be deported soon, but his movements remain restricted.
content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An American environmental journalist accused of violating the terms of his visa has been freed after three days in jail and is likely to be deported soon, a top Indonesian government minister said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Legalized Bribery by Elites Is Here to Stay. Now What?
description: Conservatives have won a generational lock on the highest courts, entrenching Citizens United. But the courts aren’t the only way to bring change.
content: This week marked 10 years since the Supreme Court’s landmark Citizens United v. FEC decision, which opened a floodgate for wealthy donors and corporate money’s flow into politics. And with the exception of a few anniversary articles, like this one, it largely went unnoticed. That’s because the world Citizens United created — unlimited money in politics and legally unchallenged corporate personhood — is now simply the toxic civic air we breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: At Border of 2 Nuclear-Armed Nations: Machine Guns, Anxiety and Dancing
description: Every evening along the India-Pakistan border, the two sides stage enormous nationalistic pep rallies, whose highlight is a military “stomp-off.”
content: ALONG THE INDIA-PAKISTAN BORDER — Long before the action starts, the crowd starts building, thousands of people, from all walks of life, inexorably pulled toward each other from two different directions — children riding their fathers’ shoulders, young mothers walking briskly beside them, older folks struggling to keep up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Team, Opening Defense, Accuses Democrats of Plot to Subvert Election
description: President Trump’s lawyers argued against his removal in the Senate impeachment trial, saying Democrats are “asking you to tear up all of the ballots” by convicting him of high crimes and misdemeanors.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s legal defense team mounted an aggressive offense on Saturday as it opened its side in the Senate impeachment trial by attacking his Democratic accusers as partisan witch-hunters trying to remove him from office because they could not beat him at the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Ben Protess
title: Tape Made Public of Trump Discussing Ukraine With Donors
description: The recording from a dinner in 2018 showed that the president spent an hour with two key players in the Ukraine pressure campaign. He has repeatedly said he does not know them.
content: WASHINGTON — For more than an hour one evening in 2018, President Trump sat around a dinner table in a private suite in his Washington hotel with a group of donors, including two men at the center of the impeachment inquiry, talking about golf, trade, politics — and removing the United States ambassador to Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Thomas Kaplan
title: ‘Good Not to Be In Washington’: Senators Return to Iowa for Burst of Campaigning
description: Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar hit the 2020 campaign trail on Saturday during a break in the impeachment trial.
content: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Senators Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar dashed back to Iowa for a frenzied burst of campaigning on Saturday after a week in which they were confined to Washington for the impeachment trial of President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Deciding When to Downsize and Move to the City
description: Sometimes, the decision to move is made for you. But sometimes you just want a change. Here’s how to work through your options.
content: Q: In the 1980s, when our children were very young, my husband and I left Park Slope, Brooklyn, for Levittown to raise our family, even though neither of us were from Long Island. Our children are now grown and have moved back to the city, where we visit them frequently. We’re interested in moving back to Brooklyn, but we’re torn. We’re in our early 60s, so how would we adjust to being renters again? Or to owning an apartment rather than a house? I’d miss having a backyard and my husband likes coming home to the suburbs. When do we know it’s time to move?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Schiff sought to head off the defense. Now it’s coming for him.
description: President Trump’s defense team wasted little time on Saturday coming straight after the House managers on the process, playing a clip at the outset of Mr. Schiff at a hearing last year
content: Representative Adam B. Schiff of California, the lead House manager, saw it coming. As he closed out opening arguments Friday night, he warned senators that they would soon hear from President Trump’s defense team about how unfair his impeachment inquiry was — and not by accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Deciding When to Downsize and Move to the City
description: Sometimes, the decision to move is made for you. But sometimes you just want a change. Here’s how to work through your options.
content: Q: In the 1980s, when our children were very young, my husband and I left Park Slope, Brooklyn, for Levittown to raise our family, even though neither of us were from Long Island. Our children are now grown and have moved back to the city, where we visit them frequently. We’re interested in moving back to Brooklyn, but we’re torn. We’re in our early 60s, so how would we adjust to being renters again? Or to owning an apartment rather than a house? I’d miss having a backyard and my husband likes coming home to the suburbs. When do we know it’s time to move?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Day 4 of Trump’s Trial: The Case for Obstruction
description: The House managers rest their case. For now.
content: Friday was crunch time for the House managers in the Senate’s impeachment trial of President Trump. It was their third and final day of opening arguments — which, to review, in most trials would be merely the start of their case. But in these jury-rigged proceedings, run by a Republican Senate leadership keen to block witnesses and other evidence in the rush toward what most expect to be a precooked acquittal, opening arguments may be as good as it gets for the prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Schiff sought to head off the defense. Now it’s coming for him.
description: President Trump’s defense team wasted little time on Saturday coming straight after the House managers on the process, playing a clip at the outset of Mr. Schiff at a hearing last year
content: Representative Adam B. Schiff of California, the lead House manager, saw it coming. As he closed out opening arguments Friday night, he warned senators that they would soon hear from President Trump’s defense team about how unfair his impeachment inquiry was — and not by accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: The president’s lawyers omit a few facts about Ukraine’s dealings.
description: One lawyer said the Ukrainians “did not even know that the security assistance was on hold until the end of August.” But Ukrainian officials knew about the suspension in assistance by late July.
content: A deputy White House counsel, Michael Purpura, correctly pointed out that President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has publicly denied that President Trump pressured him. But Gordon D. Sondland, the American ambassador to the European Union, testified that he told Mr. Zelensky’s top advisers of the demand by Mr. Trump to announce investigations. Veteran diplomats say that Mr. Zelensky could not be expected to publicly criticize Mr. Trump when he so badly needs the United States’s support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Race/Related: ‘You Killed My Brother’
description: How the tragic death of one son at the hands of the police set in motion the death of another.
content: I am a first-generation Haitian-American and I remember, when I was about 9 years old, asking my father why he moved to the United States from Haiti. “Because I wanted you and your sisters to have every opportunity I didn’t have,” he told me. From that moment on, I’ve tried my best not to disappoint my father, knowing how much he sacrificed to make sure I had a good education and a good life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Schiff was eager to hear whistle-blower testimony, defense team says.
description: “Our primary interest right now is making sure that that person is protected,” the lawmaker said in October.
content: Patrick Philbin, another deputy White House counsel, used a portion of his time to suggest that Representative Adam B. Schiff initially wanted to hear testimony from the whistle-blower whose complaint helped force the Ukraine matter in to the open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Branding Trump a Danger, Democrats Cap the Case for His Removal
description: On the final day of their oral arguments, House impeachment managers called President Trump a danger to the nation.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats concluded their arguments against President Trump on Friday by portraying his pressure campaign on Ukraine as part of a dangerous pattern of Russian appeasement that demanded his removal from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Nancy Drew Is Dead! Don't Worry, the Hardy Boys Are on the Case.
description: A new comic book series imagines that Nancy has been killed, infuriating some fans of the unstoppable teen detective who made her debut 90 years ago.
content: The Hardy Boys stand over Nancy Drew’s grave. The beloved teen detective, who has survived countless scrapes, cliffhangers and close calls, is dead — or so it seems — killed while pursuing a high-stakes investigation of organized crime. And it’s up to the Hardy Boys to solve the mystery of her murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: White House jabs at the length of the House managers’ case.
description: The strategy reminds senators of how much repetition there was in the House managers’ case and may earn some good will from the senators.
content: President Trump’s lawyers appear to have noticed how restless senators got during the more than 21 hours of arguments by the House Democratic managers over three days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Democrats rebut White House case, point by point.
description: Lawmakers accused the president’s lawyers of a presentation with little substance.
content: Immediately after the White House lawyers finished their opening arguments on Saturday, Democrats sought to pick the presentation apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Julian E. Barnes
title: In Limelight Again, Key Impeachment Witnesses Still Experience a Divided Response
description: Some have been cheered again by admirers while others are drawing a new round of insults and invective from supporters of Mr. Trump — and even from the president himself.
content: WASHINGTON — Admirers still stop and thank them on the street and in airports, send fan mail and sometimes even offer to pay for their meals. But supporters of President Trump still insult and threaten them online — even the ones who work in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Look at how the Senate transforms into a courtroom.
description: To offer a more comprehensive look at how the chamber has been transformed into a courtroom, The New York Times sent a graphics editor to draw it.
content: The video cameras in the Senate are controlled by government employees, trained mostly on one area during the impeachment trial — the front of the room where the chief justice and those speaking at the lectern appear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Day 4 of Trump’s Trial: The Case for Obstruction
description: The House managers rest their case. For now.
content: Friday was crunch time for the House managers in the Senate’s impeachment trial of President Trump. It was their third and final day of opening arguments — which, to review, in most trials would be merely the start of their case. But in these jury-rigged proceedings, run by a Republican Senate leadership keen to block witnesses and other evidence in the rush toward what most expect to be a precooked acquittal, opening arguments may be as good as it gets for the prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: The president’s lawyers omit a few facts about Ukraine’s dealings.
description: One lawyer said the Ukrainians “did not even know that the security assistance was on hold until the end of August.” But Ukrainian officials knew about the suspension in assistance by late July.
content: A deputy White House counsel, Michael Purpura, correctly pointed out that President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has publicly denied that President Trump pressured him. But Gordon D. Sondland, the American ambassador to the European Union, testified that he told Mr. Zelensky’s top advisers of the demand by Mr. Trump to announce investigations. Veteran diplomats say that Mr. Zelensky could not be expected to publicly criticize Mr. Trump when he so badly needs the United States’s support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Tries to Upstage Drama in the Senate With His Own Programming
description: While Democrats and Republicans debate whether he should be convicted and removed from office, the president has offered up an alternative menu of events and priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — On the chilly grounds of the National Mall, within sight of the gleaming white Capitol where he is on trial for high crimes and misdemeanors, President Trump on Friday rallied abortion opponents gathered for their annual march and equated their battle with his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Wang Qiang, Fresh From Upsetting Serena, Now Believes She Belongs
description: The Chinese player, seeded 27th and headed for the fourth round of the Australian Open, has spent months building up her strength — and confidence.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Wang Qiang says she lost so quickly to Serena Williams in the United States Open quarterfinals last year that it hardly left a mark: 6-1, 6-0, 44 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Senators prepare for the next phase of the trial.
description: Both sides are readying for written questions to the House prosecutors and lawyers for the White House delivered through Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.
content: President Trump’s defense is only beginning but already senators on both sides are preparing for the next phase — written questions to the House prosecutors and lawyers for the White House delivered through Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Managers seek to prove Trump is a future threat.
description: Representative Jason Crow of Colorado told senators that the goal of impeachment was to “protect against future presidential misconduct that would endanger democracy and the rule of law.”
content: As they wrap up their case, House managers have one final task: Prove that President Trump is a future threat, not just a past one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: See How 7 Grammy Artists Made Their Hits
description: Taylor Swift, Billie Eilish, Lil Nas X, Lizzo and more reveal their creative processes in our Diary of a Song series.
content: The 62nd annual Grammy Awards are Sunday night at 8 p.m. on CBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Schiff addresses criticism over his imitation of the president.
description: At a hearing in late September, the lawmaker portrayed “the essence” of the real call by pretending the president was a mobster shaking someone down.
content: Representative Adam B. Schiff, the lead House manager, for the first time took head-on the Republican criticism that he mocked President Trump during a hearing by pretending the president’s call with his Ukrainian counterpart was a mob shakedown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Race/Related: ‘You Killed My Brother’
description: How the tragic death of one son at the hands of the police set in motion the death of another.
content: I am a first-generation Haitian-American and I remember, when I was about 9 years old, asking my father why he moved to the United States from Haiti. “Because I wanted you and your sisters to have every opportunity I didn’t have,” he told me. From that moment on, I’ve tried my best not to disappoint my father, knowing how much he sacrificed to make sure I had a good education and a good life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Did ‘burden-sharing’ come up? Yes, it did.
description: The records examined by The New York Times — as the freeze on military aid was playing out — shows that some officials were pursuing the question of burden-sharing.
content: President Trump’s lawyer, Pat A. Cipollone, opened the defense arguments by  saying that the Trump administration’s hold on military assistance to Ukraine — which was fighting a Russian-backed incursion on its eastern border — was driven by the president’s belief that other nations were not doing their share in supporting the former Soviet republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Schiff was eager to hear whistle-blower testimony, defense team says.
description: “Our primary interest right now is making sure that that person is protected,” the lawmaker said in October.
content: Patrick Philbin, another deputy White House counsel, used a portion of his time to suggest that Representative Adam B. Schiff initially wanted to hear testimony from the whistle-blower whose complaint helped force the Ukraine matter in to the open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Branding Trump a Danger, Democrats Cap the Case for His Removal
description: On the final day of their oral arguments, House impeachment managers called President Trump a danger to the nation.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats concluded their arguments against President Trump on Friday by portraying his pressure campaign on Ukraine as part of a dangerous pattern of Russian appeasement that demanded his removal from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Nancy Drew Is Dead! Don't Worry, the Hardy Boys Are on the Case.
description: A new comic book series imagines that Nancy has been killed, infuriating some fans of the unstoppable teen detective who made her debut 90 years ago.
content: The Hardy Boys stand over Nancy Drew’s grave. The beloved teen detective, who has survived countless scrapes, cliffhangers and close calls, is dead — or so it seems — killed while pursuing a high-stakes investigation of organized crime. And it’s up to the Hardy Boys to solve the mystery of her murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Impeachment Briefing: Working on the Weekend
description: White House lawyers made their first formal case against the impeachment of their boss.
content: Read our full story on the day. Here are some highlights from the session. And here’s video from Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Iran Says Its Enriched Uranium Stockpile Is Far Beyond Allowed Amount
description: Iran has stockpiled 1,200 kilograms, or about 2,600 pounds, which is well beyond what the 2015 nuclear deal between Tehran and world powers allowed, an official said.
content: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Iran’s enriched uranium stockpile has far exceeded the level allowed by its international nuclear deal, an aide to Iran’s nuclear chief said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Iraq Police Crack Down on Protests as Influential Cleric Withdraws Support
description: Security forces took back bridges and squares in Baghdad and Basra after the prominent Shiite cleric, Moktada al-Sadr, said he would no longer intervene on protesters’ behalf.
content: BAGHDAD — Iraqi government security forces on Saturday took back ground from protesters in Baghdad and Basra, in an apparent bid to quell the demonstrations that have lasted for nearly four months amid calls for new elections and an end to government corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahim Abed and Mujib Mashal
title: Girl and Her Father Are Killed by Afghan Forces
description: The girl was shot dead in southern Afghanistan, and when her father took her body to a military base to ask for justice, he was killed.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government said on Saturday that it was investigating the fatal shootings by Afghan soldiers of a girl and her father in Kandahar Province, amid complaints by residents that the security forces have for years been accused of extrajudicial killings and other abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Pompeo Denounces News Media, Undermining U.S. Message on Press Freedom
description: In an extraordinary statement, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized a veteran NPR reporter, Mary Louise Kelly, and said the news media was “unhinged.”
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo escalated his clash with a respected NPR journalist on Saturday, lashing out at her and what he called the “unhinged” news media in an extraordinary statement. A day earlier, he abruptly ended an interview with her and delivered what the news outlet described as a profanity-laced rant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Hampton and Caitlin Dickerson
title: ‘Demeaned and Humiliated’: What Happened to These Iranians at U.S. Airports
description: Since August, at least 16 Iranian students have been turned away at airports, losing their chances to study at prestigious universities, amid new tensions between the U.S. and Iran.
content: A small room. A language barrier. An interrogation after hours of travel. Months spent preparing for a new life overseas, all gone in a blur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Tiffany May
title: Effects of Coronavirus Begin Echoing Far From Wuhan Epicenter
description: Hong Kong closed its schools for several weeks, Beijing began limiting bus travel in and out of the capital and China’s travel association suspended tour groups of citizens heading overseas.
content: WUHAN, China — The repercussions from a mysterious virus that has sickened hundreds of people began reverberating far from its epicenter in central China on Saturday, as Hong Kong closed its schools for several weeks, Beijing began restricting buses in and out of the capital, and the country’s travel association suspended Chinese tour groups heading overseas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler and Alexandra Alter
title: As ‘American Dirt’ Racks Up Sales, Its Author Becomes the Story
description: Jeanine Cummins’s novel about migrants fleeing violence is a hit with booksellers, but critics have called it “trauma porn” that exploits another country’s pain.
content: “American Dirt” seemed poised to become one of this year’s biggest, buzziest books.
source.name: The New York Times
